question: In the Rutherford's alpha scattering experiment, as the impact parameter increases, the scattering angle of the alpha particle
explanation: The impact parameter (<katex>$b$</katex>) is the perpendicular distance of the velocity vector of the alpha particle from the center of the nucleus.
The scattering angle (<katex>$\theta$</katex>) is related to <katex>$b$</katex> by <katex>$b \propto \cot(\theta/2)$</katex>.
As <katex>$b$</katex> increases (particle passes further away), the repulsive force is weaker, so the scattering angle <katex>$\theta$</katex> decreases.
